bibl.title: Letter from [Henry Rose Carter] to Frederick F. Russell, June 17, 1923

div1.p: [Carter] discusses the selection and training of yellow fever workers.

div1.head: Letter from [Henry Rose Carter] to Frederick F. Russell, June 17, 1923
div1.opener:
I. H. B.
Policy
/LC
2121 California St., N. W.,
Washington, D. C.,
June 17, 1923.
Dr. F. F. Russell,
General Director,
International Health Board,
61 Broadway, New York, N. Y.
Dear Doctor Russell:
div1.p:
The article by Sitjar: “Investigations on the Etiology of Yellow
Fever in the Zone of Narareth, State of Bahia, 1921,” if in the Sanidad
y Beneficencia of Habana: Vol XXV11: 1922: Page 269.

It really is of no value, as negative findings in immune reactions
under the conditions in which Stijar worked are rather to be expected.
He claims to have worked with Noguchi, which does not necessarily mean
that he is skilled in Leptospira technique. It is rather interesting
that in the history of the conveyance and control of yellow fever ne
mentions no one by name save Latin Americans. If, however, the as-
sumption of all credit by them will assist in the elimination of yel-
low fever, I have “no kick coming.”

Yesterday you evidently did not have on your list as many men as
you wanted whom you judged suitable for training for yellow fever work.
It had been better, of course, to have commenced picking out and train-
ing these men a year ago, but as we have waited this long it seems
to me that a delay of days: weeks, or even a month or so, in getting
its full complement is less important than selecting the best pos-
sible men for the job. Some, of course, you will find to be unsuitable
when they are tried out, but since you have two or three immediately
available, proper selection of the remainder is more important than speed.
